reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terra Incognita is a retro throwback RPG, hearkening back to the days of titles like Suikoden...which the developer has stated was a direct inspiration. As such, this puts somewhat of a large expectation on the game right off the bat, and after a few hours into the game, I can say that the expectations were met. There are a few small issues that I found hindered the game very slightly.  But these issues, like I said, are very small. The game is still pretty well designed, the writing is great, and the sprite work and animations are very well done.

Story-wise, it's a neat concept, conveyed through well-written dialogue. No corners were cut here, and that's great. Most smaller titles similar to this game skimp out on a lot of details, which add up to put a huge damper on the experience. Not so with Terra Incognita. I don't want to go into too much detail, as it would spoil some of the story and intrigue. Let's just say that the story is well-written and cohesive, and very good.

If you have ever played Suikoden I or II, you will immediately recognize the art style used in Terra. While it's not exactly like it, it's similar enough and looks great. Every character has a unique and detailed sprite, which shows the love and care the developer put into the art of the game. Attack and movement animations are simple, but they work and look great.

Terra uses a traditional turn-based battle system. Enemies are displayed on the left, while your party is displayed on the left. Typical status information for your party such as HP and MP is displayed in boxes at the bottom of the screen. During battle you get to choose from a list of actions for each party member: Attack, Magia (magic), Abilities, and Items. Once your actions are selected, each character performs the selected action one at a time until they are done, then the enemy performs their actions. This is repeated until one or the other party is defeated. In the case where your party is defeated, it is a game over. If the enemy is defeated, you are awarded money and experience points.

Most gamers will be famililar with the system, as it's the tried-and-true battle system for *most* RPG's out today. This means that jumping right in shouldn't be a problem for many players, and long-time fans of the genre will have no issues at all getting in there and getting their hands dirty with the mechanics of the system.

If you are looking for a cheap, deeply inspiring RPG with lots to offer, I wholeheartedly recommended Terra Incognita. The price might seem low, and because of that some people might dismiss it as being a shallow title with nothing to offer. They couldn't be more wrong!

If you're reading this then your interest has been piqued by the retro styled JRPG-alike Terra Incognita - Part 1.
This review is based on an early access build, which can currently be picked up for less than a couple of coins of your local currency.

Now that we've established the financials aren't going to make a dent in your wallet/purse, we can cut to the chase, and ask whether the game is worth your time.

If you've played any of Square (Enix) Final Fantasy series up to and include the SNES/Super Famicom FFVI, then you'll be instantly familiar with the game style.

The graphics are suitably styled in a Dragon Quest-esque manner with Suikoden undergarments, and are cohesive and consistent throughout the game world.
Random battle events occur as you explore the world map, and the game makes it easy to stay on track without (so far) a map.

Battle events are similar to Chrono Trigger and the gang with 'time wait', it would be nice to have the option to switch to a more pressing engagement, and maybe this is something the developer wishes to add.

The game starts off fairly slow, possibly due to the concussion your character receives at the very start. Once you're out of the first map though, the fragments of information begin to tell the story.

So far I've found a couple of non show-stopping bugs, which I've reported to the developer.

All in all it's nice nostalgic introduction to what will hopefully be a great story. This title has a lot of potential and I can't wait to play the final build.

Terra Incognita (Unknown Land, I guess) is an Early Access RPG about the world of Terra and the Descendants who guard it. You start the game as Alexis, a Descendant who's fallen from the sky. He meets an archer fisher dude named Leon, who gives him food and shelter for a night, and the two of them head off to the mainland for... some reason. Anyway they reach a village called North Willow, which is under constant threat of bandit attacks, so the duo try to bring peace to the northern continent, gathering friends and equipment along the way.

I played this for about half an hour. I didn't hate it. I didn't like it. Quick version, there's nothing here you'll find that you can't find in any other RPG. But on top of that, the inexperience is pretty obvious.

Positive

+Nice music

Negative

-Lag after every attack animation, entering and exiting the menu, the game just stops
-Does not offer control options until you've started the game
-Inaccurate information with the first healing spell, it will say in the 300 range even if the spell does about 500
-Can't use the first healing spell from the menu

Irritations
-This is just like any of the older Final Fantasy games, except the difference is this doesn't have anything to make it worth buying over any of them, aside from the price. It's bland.
-The animations are very minimal, even without the dead moments surrounding each one (Seriously. It just stops.) They lack any kind of feel or sense of motion or anything. There's no intensity or interest. A bit of a slow pace doesn't bother me, but there has to be something to make it worth while. They're bland.
-The enemies and characters. An armoured fighter. A woodland hunter with a bow. Forest creatures and slimes. These aren't new. They aren't interesting. They're not good. They aren't bad, either. They're forgettable and bland.
-Character shows up out of nowhere with amnesia. World has monsters that have increased in number and strength. Chosen warriors to face the looming threat. Watch your step, they've been breaking a lot of new ground around here.
-The character interrupts you when you try to walk in a way you're not supposed to go. There's a perfectly open path. But you can't go. The game doesn't want you to though, you have to wait for it to let you. Sit down and eat your vegetables and then clean up your room, then you can play. There's a good little kid.
-This is the dumbest complaint of all, but the first two playable characters have the same face and features, they face the same way in their portraits, they have a similar pose. It just looks they used the exact same template for both, and drew a beard on one.

This game is still in Early Access and this definitely seems like their maiden voyage into game development, so it should be accepted that there are going to be issues and it is mean of me to be so negative about and critical of people who want to pursue making video games. They should keep trying. But this really isn't worth playing or buying at this point. The battles are slow and more of an inconvenience than fun. The game railroads you from the start. The game stops when you do things. It's all cliché on the story front. The game isn't finished, but I'm already done with it.

That said, it is full of spelling, grammar and punctuation errors. Which is a pity because aside from that the writing is one of the few strong points of the game. Bar a few instances of recycled information.

Maps are for the most part bland, empty and boring - usually too big. They make no sense, especially the village of Window, uh, Willow - some of the inners are non-sensical, with houses being two tiles long but well over 30 inside, and others having T shaped inners and flat outers. Maps are too big, too dark when there's plenty of light sources. Light sources are also nonsensical, with shadows falling towards the light instead of away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A strange armored man falls from the sky encased in crystal, in the middle of the forest. Unhurt but loses all his memories, which is really spreading around video game main characters nowadays, having no memory of who he is other than his name. His name is Alexis, and with his new companion Leon goes on a journey to find out who he is, and to silence the strange voices in his head that keep telling him what to do. Terra Incognita ~ Chapter One: The Descendant is an Early Access Steam game, developed by Back to Basics gaming, which sets out to emulate the classic JRPGs. The name itself, translated from Latin, means “unknown land”, which is more than likely a reference to the strange, unknown land you've found yourself in.

One of the positive things about being an amnesiac is that you're figuring out the plot at the same time as Alexis is, as well as the controls. This loosely means that the small tutorial hints don't feel forced, because Alexis has no idea about what's going on, so when Leon talks to you about elemental weaknesses and Alexis asks more about. It doesn't make him that silly guy that didn't pay attention in training, he actually doesn't know. It's nicely integrated into the story's overall plot, which is a breath of fresh air considering how certain games can shove the tutorial down your throat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review


As a fan of the Suikoden series and similar titles, I fell in love with this game at first sight. It was an insta-buy for me! With such high expectaions and the huge shoes of teenage nostalgia to fill I'm proud to say this game, even in Early Access, is passing with flying colors.

Story: 10/10
I love it. I don't want to ruin anything, but this one is going places. The dialogue in this game is exactly what makes me want to play an RPG. A lot of newer RPGs have so much mindless babbling of glossary terms that you don't want to memorize. Terra Incognita has the perfect amount of vocabulary, character customization, and immersion just like it's spiritual predecessors. This is only the first chapter and I definitely want to know the rest.

Gameplay: 9/10
Anyone that's played a turn-based RPG will be familiar with the setup. It's almost just like the uniquely badass system from the Suikoden series -- you engage an enemy, choose your parties actions, attacks magic items oh my!, rinse, repeat. The amount of battles at this point is not overloading and I love a balanced experience that doesn't require farming to progress. There are a few hiccups in game mechanics, namely the lack of certain functions that I know will be polished before release.

Graphics: 9/10
The pixel art is spot on. Aside from my love for pixel art it's very in tune with the soul of the game. It almost looks like it was ripped straight from it -- doesn't look exactly look like what you think it is, but you swear it looks just like it. That's one of my favorite parts about it. :D The character portraits are also a cool blend of modern American and Japanese animation styles. The only problem is right now you can't set the window resolution or fullscreen resolution.

Sound: 10/10
The music is, simply put, perfect. It immediately brings back the memories of playing endless hours on corded controllers. The arrangements are perfect and it seems to me like their using the same instrumentation, I'm not sure but regardless, boy does it sound good to my ears.

Overall: 10/10This game has a lot of potential. For an Early Access title it has a few little user-unfriendly quirks that I hope are ironed out but it's definitely something to buy if you like RPGs or to at least watch out for when it's on sale to find that diamond in the rough for the future. For any true fan of 2D RPGs (Genesis/SNES/PSX titles alike) I'm positive you will enjoy this game. There needs to be more titles like this on Steam.

I usually avoid Early Access games like a case of syphilis, but I found this one on sale (as many people did) for a handful of change and decided to give it a shot.

At the time of this review, I've played a couple hours and I'm pretty pleased that I invested, even though the price was dirt-cheap and thus not much of a risk.  I would absolutely pay the full (and still cheap!) EA price given the choice again.

As RPGs go, it's pretty standard form, but it plays smoothly and the story looks like it'll be pretty interesting.  Since I personally prefer turn-based combat (I like having time to think rather than just reacting), I find that old-school style very entertaining.

Music and sound are done nicely as are the graphics.  There are no voiceovers, at least so far, and that's just fine with me; I'd rather have no voice work at all rather than risk bad voice-actors.  Just my personal preference.

Anyway, it's worth the buck to play if you like old-school RPGs.  And as I understand, investing in the EA gets you access to the whole finished game, which will be priced higher, so you save some money too.  If you like the game, this is a great bonus, and if you don't like it, you're still only out a dollar.  Give it a try!

(This is a rather short review to help to get this game more attention and also because this game is still in early access)

Terra Incognita is an RPG that looks to be rather promising. It has a good story with pretty likeable characters, although their personalities feel rather underdeveloped. More depth to the characters' personalities would really help to make the story stronger, but this game is still in early access; I'm sure that more will be added to them as time goes by.  As for the graphics... they're subpar. The battle animations seem very limited (which is probably due to the game being in early access), and movement seems awkward. But, once again, the game is in early access, so this is rather minor. I am rather impressed by the music in the game - it really does help to set the tone of scenes and environments. Gameplay is your typical turn-based format with not much else to it. Some may be put off by this as it doesn't really contribute anything new to the world of RPGs, but, honestly, it doesn't bother me in the slighest; I like a simple RPG like this as it's easy to pick up and progress through the game.

Also, it's currently on sale at 14 cents. You can't go wrong with buying a game when you can sell the cards to break even :P

While the game still needs some work, it's definitely a game that I'd recommend to someone who enjoys a good RPG. I hope to see more from this game as it continues to develop further as I am enjoying it so far.

I've only played about 30 minutes of this game, but I'm already hooked on the story.

This game is pretty rough at the moment, which should be expected of an early access game. I'm not entirely sure why it's early access considering the game is a story-driven RPG. Generally, early access games are either sandbox, puzzle, or shoot-em-up games; so having an RPG story as early access is a bit off-putting.

I enjoy the game, but not some of the mechanics. The option menu only allows me to change the volume and switch between full screen and windowed. It doesn't allow me to change the text speed, which I really need. Honestly, the text feels laggy. For example, someone says something, *I hit z*, *pause*, person continues with text. It feels like someone is pulsing the brakes on the story every time that happens.

The battle screen also feels laggy. The animations of the battles can be buggy too. But the battles are really simple, which I can appreciate.

The music for the game is amazing as well. I really enjoy it and wouldn't mind having a soundtrack for it to put in my game music library!

Honestly, tl;dr, this game is buggy and feels laggy. But with a little tender loving care, it will turn into a great game. I recommend this game for the story and to support the dev.

Note to the dev: Keep working on this game to make it shine!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this first opinion, I have to admit that I am only about an hour in... so please take all that with a grain of salt.  Any criticism or praise will hopefully help with further versions of this game.

First off, I will go ahead and state that an hour into it... minus a few grammatical errors, the story seems promising.  It is enough to make me want to go further into the game and I have to give props to the developer on that.  I know that a lot of the RPG maker games have a reputation for being complete ♥♥♥♥ in that department.

The music selection isn't too bad, but I feel like some of the pieces initially are out of place a little.  For instance, when heading into the Wilderness outside Willow, it seems like the music there would be more appropriate for a world map kind of song.  I got the impression that the Wilderness is supposed to be a place that is mysterious and dangerous, they literally don't know what's going on.  The music just seems like it doesn't fit the tone.  Battle music is spot on though, even if the victory music is a little annoying.

I am kind of curious to see how big some of these stat numbers get by the end of the game.  It seems like with a lot of these games, people figure than bigger is better and that isn't always the case.  Any time you start off at level 1 with almost 1000 hp, things seem a little inflated.  I know that some of that may be a little beyond the control of the developer as they were dealing with the parameters of RPG maker, but it makes me expect ridiculous high stat numbers by the end of the game.

Speaking of bigger not always being better, my biggest complaint is that it seems like there's just a lot of wasted space on the maps.  Everything is spread out and it almost feels like filler just going from one area to another to artificially create added length.  I do not believe that was the developer's intent, it just seems like things are waaaaay too big.  One of the things most 2D rpgs have done in the past was to adjust the scale of buildings from the outside, not the case here.  I hope that a run feature is added in eventually or becomes available later in the game.

Either way, I say this is definitely worth the cost of purchase.  It seems like a decent little time sink and a very good value for what I paid for it.  I hope the developer stays active on updating this game and improving it down the road, because at this point I plan to play to completion

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just bought it for fourteen cents during the little sale it had, thought it looked like a cute and charming little homage to older RPGs, boy was I wrong. Where do I begin with the flaws of this puppy though?

Controls: The controls are basic and easy to understand; can't go wrong with up down left right space enter etc, and remapping them is easy enough. Nothing negative to say here.

Graphics: The art design looked pretty original when I booted this up; though the fullscreen didn't work very well as the black side-bars were flashing various colours, mostly white and it kinda gave me a headache. The intro screen for a new game is quite nicely drawn and I expected the quality of that to go deeper once you get into the meat of the game, but the opening sequence was pretty terrible. I should have guessed it from the text actually; you could tell the developer wasn't really experienced with grammar as a whole, but I digress. Moving on to the main points you could say that the graphics are kind of slugish and sloppy; most of the actions that the characters make is very stiff and jumpy, and the game glitches out a lot. This isn't a PC issue either as I've been able to play Far Cry 4 on the highest setting with no lag what so ever - it's a design and or coding issue. Overall I'd say this needs some serious polish.

Sound: Oh my god the first song in the game when you see the fisherman talking is absolutely over used and terrible. I expected this game to have some gimmicky music and some silly FL-Studios based songs, but to use free-ware music is just a big no no. When you listen to the crystal breaking it's the same little sound three times in a row as well and that is like listening to a Wilhelm scream if you know what I mean. Overall the sound is very poor and unoriginal, kind of almost lazy in how the developer threw it in there too as the trigger-cues are off a few seconds on occasion.

Gameplay: Not too hard at all, though health, magic and what not are kind of all over the place. What I mean by that is simple; you start off with a jumbled number of health, it doesn't even have any consistant upgrades to it - it's just all over the place. You never want to start a game doing hundreds of damage either and your characters basically rip through everything with ease, while taking hundreds of points of damage. It would have been easier and more satisfying for the gamer to have earned that kind of power rather than to just be gifted it. I felt like I started half way into an adventure pretty much, it wasn't fun. The walking animation is extremely choppy as well and that ties into game play; exploration is a chore because of this, you always feel like you're going through mud and watching your character lurch forward to take a step is just sad. Overall the gameplay is basic during combat situations, but horrible otherwise. Oh and menu navigation is slow / can't skip cutscenes or tutorials etc.

In the end I'm glad I bought this for $0.14, though I feel ripped off almost. This is the kind of stuff I would release as a pre-alpha" on Byond.com using a more visual c++ style of coding. This is what I'd call brain-storming mode where considering a kick starter or an alpha release isn't even viable as a logical option.

Don't buy this for over five cents

This is a game not unlike many other RPGs in that there's an inherent amount of quality lost. Not graphically, though you can't be too boastful of that either (and yes I recognize that the game is supposed to look like it.), but in it's gameplay. I've only played 17 minnutes but I can already tell I won't like it, luckily it was gifted to me when it was 17 cents so I doubt the person who gifted it to me will lose much sleep over me saying that I truly dislike this game, very much.

Let's start out with the pros.
- Looks decent for what I assume to be an indie game.
- The music is... okay.
- The battle system is easy to grasp, as it's very similar to Final Fantasy.

And here's some cons:
- The battle system is TOO easy to grasp, as it's exactly the same as Final Fantasy's but less functional and slower.
- Movement is slow.
- The forest area isn't terribly exciting.
- The monsters aren't unique in any way.

I'd recommend this game to someone if they'd never played another game in this genre bfore, or never even heard of Final Fantasy, because I'm sure without those experiences, I'd enjoy this game. But I don't. No offense to the creators, as I'm sure there is a target audience. I'm just saying that you should beware as to whether you fall into that target audience or not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

$1.00 is a fantastic price for an RPG, so I won't be too hard on it. I'll just be straight up.

Pros:
- The buildings and environment look amazing. It'll take you back to the old feeling you once had!

Cons:
Early Access - (I hope these get fixed!)
- No auto-run. You need to hold SHIFT if you want to run. Please, make it so once you click SHIFT once you will auto-run until you hit SHIFT again.
- Not able to run indoors. Frustrating to enter a building and you can't run. Speaking of the whole auto-run (or lack thereof), I don't know why anybody would choose to walk. I think having a default run character would be great. No need to have walk as an option.
- The animations during combat don't sync up that well. If an enemy attacks me and I use a spell right after, the spell will hit in the location they were at to attack me instead of where they currently are at.
- Grammatical errors. Lots of them! While I'm not trying to be anal about it, I don't see how not capitalizing a character's name would get by. The smaller ones such as a misuse or non-existent comma are understandable.

Funny Stuff!:
Not to be taken seriously
- Title screen music reminds me of 'Band of Horses' - 'The Funeral'
- Get yelled at for trying to enter a house uninvited! Come on now, in an RPG you can't enter somebody's house, loot it and leave without repercussions!?
- 2 hours long. A 2 hour long (early access) RPG? Where are the 10+ hour RPGs I grew up with?

Overall I like this game and I hope the developer(s) fix the bugs/glitches/errors and ultimately create a successful game (series). Be seeing you in the future for the next patch and/or offical release!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terra Incognita overall is a very nostalgic game and reminds me of The older Legend of Zelda and Final Fantasy franchise games. Because this game is still in beta, there are obviously still aspects of the game that can be improved upon.
Such as:-
- The game's controls, the remap menu is very confusing and I could not undertstand which control was what. I tried playing with a gamepad and the controls there were also very confusing to use. This may be because I was using a Dualshock 4 controller through DS4 Windows therefore converting it to a 360 gamepad, but I highly doubt it as I have had no trouble before.

- A run option should be added to the battle menu. It gets quite annoying when you are trying to progress through the game and you get random battles popping up all the time.

- The Steam Overlay is also not availabe in-game. This might be just my computer I play in fullscreen mode. If anyone else if having trouble with this then I suggest reporting it.

- When you try and 'Tab out' of the game in fullscreen mode, the image of the game is still visible on screen and prevents me from seeing anything behind the image. Only closing the game seems to fix this. This is very annoying as if I need to do something when Im in the middle of playing I have to close the game and then re-open and continue from when I last saved.

However despite this game's flaws I feel that if the developer puts in some extra time and effort into fully finishing the game and possibly expanding the plot then this could become a very popular franchise. The feeling of nostalgia when playing this game brings back great memories from some of the original RPG Adventure games like Zelda and if this game is completed, it could one day give Zelda a run for its money!
